content.text: the existing intellectual property that the developer embeds or incorporates into the results of development are generally referred to ‘background IPRs’ or ‘pre-existing IPRs’.

content.verbatim_text: Intellectual property rights or IPRs are the rights given to individuals or companies over their inventions or other creations.
content.plain_text: Intellectual property rights (IPRs) are rights granted to individuals or companies for their inventions or creations.
content.expert_insight: IPRs are fundamental legal protections for creative and innovative works, granting creators control over their use.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Intellectual property rights or IPRs are the rights given to individuals or companies over their inventions or other creations.

content.verbatim_text: They usually give the inventor/creator an exclusive right over the use of its invention/creation for a certain period of time.
content.plain_text: IPRs typically grant the inventor or creator an exclusive right to use their invention or creation for a specific duration.
content.expert_insight: This exclusivity is a core feature of IPRs, incentivizing innovation by allowing creators to control and profit from their work for a limited period.
content.justification: Explains the nature of the right granted by IPRs.
content.implication_company: When Zebracorp owns IPRs, it has exclusive control over their use. When it licenses IPRs, its use is subject to the license terms.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers holding IPRs can control how others, including Zebracorp, use their inventions/creations.
content.source_insight: The text describes a general characteristic of IPRs.
content.text: They usually give the inventor/creator an exclusive right over the use of its invention/creation for a certain period of time.

content.verbatim_text: The most common types of intellectual property rights include patents, copyrights and trademarks.
content.plain_text: Common types of intellectual property rights are patents, copyrights, and trademarks.
content.expert_insight: These three categories represent the primary forms of IPRs, each protecting different aspects of innovation and branding.
content.justification: Lists the primary categories of IPRs.
content.implication_company: Helps Zebracorp identify which type of protection is relevant for its assets or those it acquires.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should be aware of these types to protect their own innovations and brands.
content.source_insight: Provides a general overview of IPR types.
content.text: The most common types of intellectual property rights include patents, copyrights and trademarks.

content.verbatim_text: Patents are granted by state authorities in various countries to certain inventions that provide a solution to a specific technological problem.
content.plain_text: Patents are state-granted rights for inventions that solve a specific technological problem.
content.expert_insight: Patents are a powerful tool for protecting technological advancements, requiring formal application and approval from government bodies.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Patents are granted by state authorities in various countries to certain inventions that provide a solution to a specific technological problem.

content.verbatim_text: In order to be patentable, the invention must meet relevant patentability requirements, such as novelty, usefulness and nonobviousness.
content.plain_text: For an invention to be patentable, it must satisfy specific requirements, including novelty, usefulness, and non-obviousness.
content.expert_insight: These are the core criteria for patent eligibility globally. Failing any one of these will result in a rejected patent application.
content.conditions: An invention must be novel, useful, and non-obvious.
content.justification: States explicit requirements for patentability.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must ensure its inventions meet these criteria before attempting to patent them, or when evaluating supplier patents.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must ensure their inventions meet these criteria to secure patent protection.
content.source_insight: Directly states the conditions for patentability.
content.text: In order to be patentable, the invention must meet relevant patentability requirements, such as novelty, usefulness and nonobviousness.

content.verbatim_text: The exclusive right granted to a patent holder is not the “sole right to use” but the right to prevent others from making, using, selling, or distributing the patented invention without the patent holders’ permission.
content.plain_text: A patent grants the holder the exclusive right to prevent others from making, using, selling, or distributing the patented invention without permission, rather than a sole right to use it.
content.expert_insight: This is a crucial distinction: a patent is a 'negative right' – it grants the power to exclude, not necessarily the freedom to operate, as other patents might block the use of one's own patented invention.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: The exclusive right granted to a patent holder is not the “sole right to use” but the right to prevent others from making, using, selling, or distributing the patented invention without the patent holders’ permission.

content.verbatim_text: Copyright laws give creator of a certain piece of work exclusive rights to it.
content.plain_text: Copyright laws grant exclusive rights to the creator of a specific work.
content.expert_insight: Copyright protects original works of authorship, providing creators with control over reproduction, distribution, and adaptation.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Copyright laws give creator of a certain piece of work exclusive rights to it.

content.verbatim_text: In order to obtain copyright the work should meet minimal standards of originality.
content.plain_text: To obtain copyright, a work must meet minimal standards of originality.
content.expert_insight: Originality is the cornerstone of copyright protection, meaning the work must be independently created and possess a modicum of creativity. It does not require novelty.
content.conditions: The work must meet minimal standards of originality.
content.justification: States a direct requirement for copyright.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp's creative works must be original to qualify for copyright protection.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers' works must be original to be copyrighted.
content.source_insight: Directly states the condition for obtaining copyright.
content.text: In order to obtain copyright the work should meet minimal standards of originality.

content.verbatim_text: Trademarks are distinctive names, symbols or designs or combination of all of the above, that identify a company or products and services.
content.plain_text: Trademarks are distinctive names, symbols, designs, or combinations thereof, used to identify a company or its products and services.
content.expert_insight: Trademarks serve as source identifiers in the marketplace, helping consumers distinguish goods and services from different providers.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Trademarks are distinctive names, symbols or designs or combination of all of the above, that identify a company or products and services.

content.verbatim_text: Trademarks provide their owners with the legal right to prevent others from using a confusingly similar trademark.
content.plain_text: Trademark owners have the legal right to prevent others from using a confusingly similar trademark.
content.expert_insight: This right protects consumers from confusion about the source of goods or services and safeguards the brand owner's reputation and investment.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Trademarks provide their owners with the legal right to prevent others from using a confusingly similar trademark.

content.verbatim_text: However, in development agreements or any such agreements where the supplier is contracted to deliver certain work results to Zebracorp (in e.g. consultancy agreements) we should expressly agree on the ownership of the results of the development or other work.
content.plain_text: In development agreements or similar contracts where a supplier delivers work results to Zebracorp, explicit agreement on the ownership of these results is required.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical point to prevent future disputes over who controls the intellectual property generated. Ambiguity can lead to significant legal and commercial challenges.
content.conditions: Applies to development agreements or contracts where a supplier delivers work results to Zebracorp (e.g., consultancy agreements).
content.justification: Explicitly states an action that 'we should expressly agree on'.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must proactively negotiate and document IPR ownership in development-focused contracts to secure its rights.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should be prepared to discuss and agree on IPR ownership for work results delivered to Zebracorp.
content.source_insight: The text highlights a specific contractual obligation for Zebracorp.
content.text: However, in development agreements or any such agreements where the supplier is contracted to deliver certain work results to Zebracorp (in e.g. consultancy agreements) we should expressly agree on the ownership of the results of the development or other work.

content.verbatim_text: In the absence of such agreement, the IPRs will generally vest with the party that made the invention or created the work.
content.plain_text: If there is no explicit agreement on IPR ownership, the rights will typically belong to the party that invented or created the work.
content.expert_insight: This is the default legal position in many jurisdictions (creator ownership). Relying on this default without explicit agreement can be risky, especially for commissioned works, as it may not align with Zebracorp's commercial objectives.
content.conditions: Absence of an explicit agreement on IPR ownership.
content.justification: States the general default rule for IPR vesting.
content.implication_company: Without an agreement, Zebracorp may not own the IPRs for work it commissioned and paid for, potentially losing control and exploitation rights.
content.implication_supplier: Without an agreement, suppliers would typically retain ownership of IPRs they create, even if commissioned by Zebracorp.
content.source_insight: Provides the default legal outcome if no agreement is made.
content.text: In the absence of such agreement, the IPRs will generally vest with the party that made the invention or created the work.

content.verbatim_text: Whenever Zebracorp intends to order professional services such as in e.g. design/development work, consulting work, integration work or customizations, it is important to agree on the ownership of the development/service results.
content.plain_text: When Zebracorp orders professional services like design, development, consulting, integration, or customizations, it is crucial to agree on the ownership of the resulting deliverables.
content.expert_insight: This reiterates the importance of proactive IPR negotiation in service contracts, especially for custom-created outputs, to ensure Zebracorp secures the rights it needs.
content.conditions: Zebracorp orders professional services (design/development, consulting, integration, customizations).
content.justification: Emphasizes the importance of agreeing on ownership.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must prioritize IPR ownership discussions in service contracts to avoid future disputes and ensure full exploitation rights.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers providing professional services should expect to negotiate and agree on the ownership of the work results.
content.source_insight: Highlights a key requirement for Zebracorp's contracts.
content.text: Whenever Zebracorp intends to order professional services such as in e.g. design/development work, consulting work, integration work or customizations, it is important to agree on the ownership of the development/service results.

content.verbatim_text: Most Zebracorp procurement contract templates transfer the ownership to Zebracorp by default. This is largely because Zebracorp pays for the services and therefore it is reasonable to expect that we also receive unrestricted rights to exploit and make use of those work results that we have paid for.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp's standard procurement contracts typically transfer IPR ownership to Zebracorp by default, as it pays for the services and expects unrestricted rights to use the deliverables.
content.expert_insight: This reflects Zebracorp's strong baseline position, aligning payment with ownership. It sets the expectation for suppliers that Zebracorp will seek full ownership for commissioned work.
content.justification: Explains Zebracorp's default contractual position and its rationale.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp's templates are designed to secure IPR ownership, simplifying negotiations in many cases.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers contracting with Zebracorp should expect to transfer IPR ownership for paid services unless otherwise negotiated.
content.source_insight: Describes Zebracorp's standard practice and its underlying reasoning.
content.text: Most Zebracorp procurement contract templates transfer the ownership to Zebracorp by default. This is largely because Zebracorp pays for the services and therefore it is reasonable to expect that we also receive unrestricted rights to exploit and make use of those work results that we have paid for.

content.verbatim_text: “All right, title and interest in and to all Intellectual Property Rights in or related to any [Results of Services], shall vest in and become the sole and exclusive property of [ZEBRACORP]. If and to the extent it is impossible as a matter of law to transfer ownership in Intellectual Property Rights to [ZEBRACORP], the [Supplier] hereby grants [ZEBRACORP] an exclusive, irrevocable, perpetual, transferable, fully paid-up, worldwide and unlimited right to use and exploit in any possible manner (including but not limited to the right to modify, copy, amend, translate, further develop, prepare derivative works of, distribute and sublicense) all Intellectual Property Rights pertaining to the [Results of Services], and warrants with respect to its representatives and any third party engaged to the performance of the [Services], that they will do the same.”
content.plain_text: An example clause where all IPRs in service results vest in Zebracorp, or if legally impossible, the supplier grants Zebracorp an exclusive, irrevocable, perpetual, transferable, fully paid-up, worldwide, and unlimited license to use and exploit them.
content.expert_insight: This robust clause aims to secure maximum rights for Zebracorp, either through ownership transfer or a comprehensive fallback license, covering all conceivable uses.
content.justification: Provides a direct example of contract language.
content.implication_company: This clause ensures Zebracorp obtains broad rights to service results, mitigating risks if direct ownership transfer is legally challenging.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers agreeing to this clause transfer significant IPR control to Zebracorp, or grant a very broad license.
content.source_insight: Directly quoted example of a default provision.
content.text: “All right, title and interest in and to all Intellectual Property Rights in or related to any [Results of Services], shall vest in and become the sole and exclusive property of [ZEBRACORP]. If and to the extent it is impossible as a matter of law to transfer ownership in Intellectual Property Rights to [ZEBRACORP], the [Supplier] hereby grants [ZEBRACORP] an exclusive, irrevocable, perpetual, transferable, fully paid-up, worldwide and unlimited right to use and exploit in any possible manner (including but not limited to the right to modify, copy, amend, translate, further develop, prepare derivative works of, distribute and sublicense) all Intellectual Property Rights pertaining to the [Results of Services], and warrants with respect to its representatives and any third party engaged to the performance of the [Services], that they will do the same.”

content.verbatim_text: Such right for the supplier should obviously specifically exclude any Zebracorp proprietary or confidential items.
content.plain_text: Any right granted to a supplier to sell service results to other customers must explicitly exclude Zebracorp's proprietary or confidential items.
content.expert_insight: This is crucial for protecting Zebracorp's sensitive information and competitive advantage. Clear exclusions prevent unintended disclosure or misuse.
content.conditions: When allowing a supplier to sell service results to other customers.
content.justification: States a necessary exclusion for supplier rights.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must ensure its proprietary and confidential information is protected if suppliers are allowed to commercialize service results.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must understand that any rights to resell service results will be limited to exclude Zebracorp's proprietary or confidential elements.
content.source_insight: Provides a specific condition for granting rights to suppliers.
content.text: Such right for the supplier should obviously specifically exclude any Zebracorp proprietary or confidential items.

content.verbatim_text: This can be addressed by adding the following type of provision: “The Parties agree that any [Intellectual Property Rights] in and to the [Service Results] shall vest in and become the sole and exclusive property of the [Buyer], save for any derivative work or other modification of the [Supplier Product] which will be owned by the [Supplier], unless otherwise expressly agreed between the Parties.”
content.plain_text: To address supplier assertions of ownership over modifications to their own products, a provision can be added stating that Zebracorp owns service results, except for derivative works or modifications of the supplier's product, which remain with the supplier unless agreed otherwise.
content.expert_insight: This is a common compromise, allowing Zebracorp ownership of the 'new' service results while respecting the supplier's underlying product IP. It requires careful definition of 'derivative work' to avoid ambiguity.
content.justification: Provides a specific contractual solution to a common negotiation point.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can use this to secure ownership of most service results while acknowledging supplier's rights to their core product modifications.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers can use this to retain ownership of modifications to their proprietary products, even when commissioned by Zebracorp.
content.source_insight: Offers a tactical solution with example language.
content.text: This can be addressed by adding the following type of provision: “The Parties agree that any [Intellectual Property Rights] in and to the [Service Results] shall vest in and become the sole and exclusive property of the [Buyer], save for any derivative work or other modification of the [Supplier Product] which will be owned by the [Supplier], unless otherwise expressly agreed between the Parties.”

content.verbatim_text: In software in-licensing agreements, we should often be in able to agree that works or modifications that change the source code of the supplier software will always be owned by the supplier/licensor of the software product.
content.plain_text: In software in-licensing agreements, it is often appropriate to agree that the supplier/licensor will retain ownership of works or modifications that alter their software's source code.
content.expert_insight: This is a practical approach as suppliers often need to maintain control over their core product's source code for updates, maintenance, and future development across their customer base.
content.conditions: Applies to software in-licensing agreements where works or modifications change the source code of supplier software.
content.justification: States a common and often appropriate agreement for specific contract types.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should be prepared to cede ownership of source code modifications to the supplier in in-licensing agreements, focusing instead on robust usage licenses.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should typically seek to retain ownership of any modifications to their core software source code.
content.source_insight: Provides guidance on a specific type of agreement.
content.text: In software in-licensing agreements, we should often be in able to agree that works or modifications that change the source code of the supplier software will always be owned by the supplier/licensor of the software product.

content.verbatim_text: It is recommend to speak to member of the product line or customer team to understand the individual needs of Zebracorp for each particular case.
content.plain_text: It is recommended to consult with the product line or customer team to understand Zebracorp's specific needs for each case.
content.expert_insight: Tailoring IPR agreements to specific business needs is crucial. Internal consultation ensures that legal strategies align with commercial objectives.
content.justification: Provides direct advice/instruction.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp personnel should engage internal stakeholders to define IPR requirements before finalizing contracts.
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: Direct instruction for internal process.
content.text: It is recommend to speak to member of the product line or customer team to understand the individual needs of Zebracorp for each particular case.

content.verbatim_text: In those global procurement contracts where the supplier refuses to grant us ownership by default, we should often seek to secure a provision where we agree that Zebracorp or its end customer specific customizations are always owned by Zebracorp.
content.plain_text: In global procurement contracts where suppliers refuse default ownership transfer, Zebracorp should aim to secure a provision ensuring that Zebracorp or its end-customer specific customizations are always owned by Zebracorp.
content.expert_insight: This is a strategic compromise. While not full ownership, it protects Zebracorp's unique investments and prevents suppliers from commercializing Zebracorp-specific developments.
content.conditions: Global procurement contracts where the supplier refuses to grant ownership by default.
content.justification: States a specific strategy to pursue in certain negotiation scenarios.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should prioritize securing ownership of its specific customizations when full ownership transfer is not possible.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers in global contracts may face demands to transfer ownership of Zebracorp-specific customizations.
content.source_insight: Provides a tactical guideline for negotiation.
content.text: In those global procurement contracts where the supplier refuses to grant us ownership by default, we should often seek to secure a provision where we agree that Zebracorp or its end customer specific customizations are always owned by Zebracorp.

content.verbatim_text: “Despite anything to the contrary, the [Buyer] will at all times become the sole and exclusive owner of any and all Intellectual Property Rights in and to any [Buyer] or its end-customer customizations and/or to any or [Service Results] that include, embed or contain or that are based, developed, created or derived from any [Buyer] or its end-customer proprietary design, specifications or intellectual property rights or trade secrets, or that are otherwise based on requirements that are unique or specific to the [Buyer] or to any of its end-customer(s)”
content.plain_text: An example clause for compromise language states that the Buyer (Zebracorp) will be the sole owner of IPRs in any Buyer or end-customer customizations, or service results based on Buyer's proprietary designs, specifications, IPRs, trade secrets, or unique requirements.
content.expert_insight: This clause is designed to capture all IPRs directly tied to Zebracorp's unique contributions or requirements, providing strong protection for its specific investments.
content.justification: Provides direct example of compromise contract language.
content.implication_company: This language helps Zebracorp secure ownership of critical, company-specific IP even when full ownership of all deliverables is not achieved.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must be aware that IPRs related to Zebracorp's specific customizations will transfer to Zebracorp.
content.source_insight: Directly quoted example of compromise language.
content.text: “Despite anything to the contrary, the [Buyer] will at all times become the sole and exclusive owner of any and all Intellectual Property Rights in and to any [Buyer] or its end-customer customizations and/or to any or [Service Results] that include, embed or contain or that are based, developed, created or derived from any [Buyer] or its end-customer proprietary design, specifications or intellectual property rights or trade secrets, or that are otherwise based on requirements that are unique or specific to the [Buyer] or to any of its end-customer(s)”

content.verbatim_text: Note that in cases where we do agree that the supplier/subcontractor retains ownership of the result of the services, it is imperative to agree on our license i.e. right to use those service results that we do not own.
content.plain_text: If Zebracorp agrees that a supplier retains ownership of service results, it is essential to secure a license (right to use) for those results.
content.expert_insight: This is non-negotiable. Without a license, Zebracorp would have no legal right to use the deliverables it paid for, rendering the service useless. The scope of this license is paramount.
content.conditions: Zebracorp agrees that the supplier/subcontractor retains ownership of service results.
content.justification: Uses strong language 'it is imperative to agree on'.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must always obtain a comprehensive license for any service results it does not own, to ensure its ability to use them.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers retaining ownership must be prepared to grant a license to Zebracorp for the commissioned work.
content.source_insight: Highlights a critical obligation for Zebracorp.
content.text: Note that in cases where we do agree that the supplier/subcontractor retains ownership of the result of the services, it is imperative to agree on our license i.e. right to use those service results that we do not own.

content.verbatim_text: This can be done by adding the following or substantially similar language: “If and to the extent the ownership of Intellectual Property Rights in the applicable [Results of Services] is not transferred or assigned to or vested with [ZEBRACORP], the [Supplier] hereby grants [ZEBRACORP] and its affiliated entities, a non- exclusive (unless the [Results of Services] are specifically created or developed for [ZEBRACORP] or its endcustomer, in which case ZEBRACORP will obtain an exclusive license), irrevocable, perpetual, transferable, fully paid-up, worldwide right to use and exploit (including but not limited to the right to modify, copy, amend, translate, further develop, prepare derivative works of, distribute and sublicense) all Intellectual Property Rights pertaining to the applicable [Results of Services]”.
content.plain_text: To secure a license for service results not owned by Zebracorp, a clause can be used where the supplier grants Zebracorp and its affiliates a non-exclusive (or exclusive if custom-developed) irrevocable, perpetual, transferable, fully paid-up, worldwide right to use and exploit all IPRs in the results.
content.expert_insight: This provides a robust license, ensuring Zebracorp has extensive rights to use the work, even without ownership. The exclusivity for custom work is a key negotiation point.
content.justification: Provides a specific contractual solution with example language.
content.implication_company: This language ensures Zebracorp has broad and lasting rights to use deliverables even if it doesn't own the IPRs.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers granting such a license provide extensive usage rights to Zebracorp, impacting their ability to commercialize the same work elsewhere.
content.source_insight: Offers a tactical solution with example language.
content.text: This can be done by adding the following or substantially similar language: “If and to the extent the ownership of Intellectual Property Rights in the applicable [Results of Services] is not transferred or assigned to or vested with [ZEBRACORP], the [Supplier] hereby grants [ZEBRACORP] and its affiliated entities, a non- exclusive (unless the [Results of Services] are specifically created or developed for [ZEBRACORP] or its endcustomer, in which case ZEBRACORP will obtain an exclusive license), irrevocable, perpetual, transferable, fully paid-up, worldwide right to use and exploit (including but not limited to the right to modify, copy, amend, translate, further develop, prepare derivative works of, distribute and sublicense) all Intellectual Property Rights pertaining to the applicable [Results of Services]”.

content.verbatim_text: We should be mindful of the fact that the IPR ownership will vest with the creator of the work (this would be the supplier) in case we have not agreed otherwise.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp should remember that IPR ownership defaults to the creator (the supplier) if no other agreement is made.
content.expert_insight: This reinforces the 'creator ownership' principle. Zebracorp must actively contract for ownership or a license, otherwise, the supplier retains rights by default.
content.justification: Provides important background information regarding default IPR ownership.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp risks not owning IPRs for commissioned work if it fails to explicitly contract for ownership or a license.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers will default to owning IPRs for their creations unless a contract specifies otherwise.
content.source_insight: Reminds Zebracorp of the default legal position.
content.text: We should be mindful of the fact that the IPR ownership will vest with the creator of the work (this would be the supplier) in case we have not agreed otherwise.

content.verbatim_text: it is nevertheless important to have a fall-back provision that determines the ownership of the IPR in the event the IPR ownership provision is omitted in the Statement of Work.
content.plain_text: It is important to include a fallback provision for IPR ownership in the main agreement, in case it is omitted from a Statement of Work.
content.expert_insight: This is a crucial risk mitigation strategy. Relying solely on SOWs for IPR can lead to gaps and disputes if SOWs are incomplete or overlooked. A master agreement fallback provides baseline protection.
content.conditions: When IPR ownership might be agreed in a Statement of Work.
content.justification: States the importance of a fallback provision.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should ensure its master agreements contain default IPR ownership provisions to cover situations where SOWs are silent.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should be aware that a master agreement might dictate IPR ownership even if an SOW is silent.
content.source_insight: Provides a specific guideline for contractual structure.
content.text: it is nevertheless important to have a fall-back provision that determines the ownership of the IPR in the event the IPR ownership provision is omitted in the Statement of Work.

content.verbatim_text: A compromise can often be found by laying out the basic rules on the division of IPRs between the supplier and Zebracorp substantially in line with the above mentioned guidelines and by leaving the option to define the ownership in more detail in the Statement of Work or, if necessary, even to deviate from these ground rules in the Statement of Work.
content.plain_text: A compromise for IPR ownership can involve establishing basic rules in the main agreement, allowing for more detailed definitions or deviations in the Statement of Work.
content.expert_insight: This 'framework agreement' approach provides flexibility while ensuring a baseline legal position. It allows for efficient SOW creation without starting IPR negotiations from scratch each time.
content.justification: Suggests a compromise strategy for IPR negotiation.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can use this approach to streamline IPR negotiations, setting general rules while allowing for case-specific adjustments.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers can benefit from clear baseline IPR rules in master agreements, with room for specific SOW adjustments.
content.source_insight: Offers a tactical approach to IPR negotiation.
content.text: A compromise can often be found by laying out the basic rules on the division of IPRs between the supplier and Zebracorp substantially in line with the above mentioned guidelines and by leaving the option to define the ownership in more detail in the Statement of Work or, if necessary, even to deviate from these ground rules in the Statement of Work.

content.verbatim_text: However, we must have a license to use these pre-existing IPRs.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp must obtain a license to use any supplier's pre-existing IPRs that are embedded in the service results.
content.expert_insight: This is absolutely essential. Even if Zebracorp owns the new work results, it cannot use them if they incorporate supplier's pre-existing IP without a license. This is a common pitfall.
content.conditions: Supplier's pre-existing IPRs are embedded into the results of services.
content.justification: Uses strong language 'we must have a license'.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must ensure all contracts include a license for any pre-existing supplier IPR necessary to use the deliverables.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should be prepared to grant a license for their pre-existing IPRs if they are embedded in deliverables for Zebracorp.
content.source_insight: Highlights a critical obligation for Zebracorp.
content.text: However, we must have a license to use these pre-existing IPRs.

content.verbatim_text: “The [Supplier] hereby grants [ZEBRACORP] an exclusive, irrevocable, perpetual, transferable, fully paid-up, worldwide and unlimited right to use and exploit in any possible manner (including but not limited the right to modify, copy, amend, translate, further develop, prepare derivative works of, distribute and sublicense) all Intellectual Property Rights pertaining to the such pre-existing copyrights if and to the extent such pre-existing copyrights are necessary for [ZEBRACORP] for the purpose of exploiting the [Results of Services] procured pursuant to this [Agreement], and the [Supplier] warrants with respect to its representatives and any third party engaged to the performance of the [Professional Services] on behalf of the [Supplier] under this [Agreement], that they will do the same.”
content.plain_text: An example license for pre-existing IPRs grants Zebracorp an exclusive, irrevocable, perpetual, transferable, fully paid-up, worldwide, and unlimited right to use and exploit such IPRs if necessary for exploiting the service results, with the supplier warranting compliance from its representatives and third parties.
content.expert_insight: This is a very comprehensive license, providing Zebracorp with maximum flexibility for using embedded pre-existing IP. The warranty clause extends this obligation to sub-contractors.
content.justification: Provides a direct example of contract language.
content.implication_company: This clause ensures Zebracorp has broad rights to use pre-existing supplier IPRs embedded in deliverables, crucial for full exploitation.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers agreeing to this grant extensive rights to their pre-existing IPRs, limiting future commercialization of those specific embedded elements.
content.source_insight: Directly quoted example of a license provision.
content.text: “The [Supplier] hereby grants [ZEBRACORP] an exclusive, irrevocable, perpetual, transferable, fully paid-up, worldwide and unlimited right to use and exploit in any possible manner (including but not limited the right to modify, copy, amend, translate, further develop, prepare derivative works of, distribute and sublicense) all Intellectual Property Rights pertaining to the such pre-existing copyrights if and to the extent such pre-existing copyrights are necessary for [ZEBRACORP] for the purpose of exploiting the [Results of Services] procured pursuant to this [Agreement], and the [Supplier] warrants with respect to its representatives and any third party engaged to the performance of the [Professional Services] on behalf of the [Supplier] under this [Agreement], that they will do the same.”

content.verbatim_text: The term ‘warrants’ at the end of the above clause can be changed to less stringent word such as ‘shall ensure’ or this warranty can be negotiated away be entirely removing the last bit that starts with: “….and the [Supplier] warrants…” . The above clause provides additional room for negotiation. The license does not need to be unlimited but it can in fact be specifically labelled as a limited license. Also the license is not required to be exclusive but we can in most cases readily consent to the above license being ‘non-exclusive’ i.e. allow the supplier to license the same pre-existing IPRs to its other customers as well.
content.plain_text: The 'warrants' term in the license clause can be negotiated to 'shall ensure' or removed. The license itself can be limited in scope and can be non-exclusive, allowing the supplier to license pre-existing IPRs to other customers.
content.expert_insight: This highlights several key negotiation points for Zebracorp to achieve a more balanced outcome, particularly around the scope and exclusivity of the license for pre-existing IP.
content.justification: Provides specific negotiation points and flexibility for the license clause.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp has flexibility to negotiate the terms of the pre-existing IPR license, potentially reducing cost or easing supplier acceptance.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers have room to negotiate the warranty, scope, and exclusivity of the license granted for their pre-existing IPRs.
content.source_insight: Offers tactical advice for negotiation.
content.text: The term ‘warrants’ at the end of the above clause can be changed to less stringent word such as ‘shall ensure’ or this warranty can be negotiated away be entirely removing the last bit that starts with: “….and the [Supplier] warrants…” . The above clause provides additional room for negotiation. The license does not need to be unlimited but it can in fact be specifically labelled as a limited license. Also the license is not required to be exclusive but we can in most cases readily consent to the above license being ‘non-exclusive’ i.e. allow the supplier to license the same pre-existing IPRs to its other customers as well.

content.verbatim_text: Unless Zebracorp obtains full ownership to any and all IPRs in the deliverables, no matter when created, it is advisable to insert a clause into the [development] agreement that supplier has no right to include any pre-existing IPR into the deliverables/Zebracorp product unless otherwise expressly agreed in writing.
content.plain_text: If Zebracorp does not obtain full ownership of all IPRs in deliverables, it is advisable to include a clause in the development agreement preventing the supplier from incorporating pre-existing IPR into Zebracorp's product unless explicitly agreed in writing.
content.expert_insight: This is a proactive measure to prevent 'IP contamination.' It ensures Zebracorp has clear title to its product without potential future claims from suppliers regarding embedded pre-existing IP.
content.conditions: Zebracorp does not obtain full ownership to any and all IPRs in the deliverables.
content.justification: States an advisable action to take in development agreements.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can prevent unintended inclusion of supplier pre-existing IPR into its products, simplifying IP management and ownership claims.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must seek explicit written agreement before embedding any of their pre-existing IPR into Zebracorp's deliverables if this clause is present.
content.source_insight: Provides a specific guideline for development agreements.
content.text: Unless Zebracorp obtains full ownership to any and all IPRs in the deliverables, no matter when created, it is advisable to insert a clause into the [development] agreement that supplier has no right to include any pre-existing IPR into the deliverables/Zebracorp product unless otherwise expressly agreed in writing.

content.verbatim_text: Whatever the adaptation is, it may be important to specifically mention that IPRs to such adaptation remain with Zebracorp.
content.plain_text: Regardless of the nature of the adaptation, it is important to explicitly state that the IPRs for such adaptations belong to Zebracorp.
content.expert_insight: Clear attribution of ownership for adaptations prevents ambiguity and ensures Zebracorp retains control over its modifications, which can be critical for competitive advantage.
content.conditions: When Zebracorp makes adaptations to supplier products.
content.justification: States the importance of explicitly mentioning IPR ownership.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should ensure its contracts clearly state its ownership of IPRs in any adaptations it makes to supplier products.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should expect Zebracorp to assert ownership over adaptations it makes to their products.
content.source_insight: Provides a guideline for IPR ownership of adaptations.
content.text: Whatever the adaptation is, it may be important to specifically mention that IPRs to such adaptation remain with Zebracorp.

content.verbatim_text: This potential bone of contention can often be resolved by defining the Zebracorp adaptation in sufficient detail and by adding clarifying language such as: “the foregoing will not be construed to transfer or assign any ownership or title to any intellectual property rights of the supplier in the underlying product but the supplier and its licensors will retain all such rights despite any adaptations made by or for [ZEBRACORP]“, or similar wording to safeguard supplier’s IP ownership in the underlying product.
content.plain_text: To resolve disputes over adaptations, define Zebracorp's adaptations in detail and include clarifying language stating that the agreement does not transfer ownership of the supplier's underlying product IPRs, which remain with the supplier.
content.expert_insight: This approach balances Zebracorp's need for adaptation ownership with the supplier's need to protect its core product IP. Precision in defining 'adaptation' is key.
content.justification: Provides a specific strategy to resolve a common point of contention.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can use this to secure ownership of its adaptations while reassuring suppliers about their underlying product IP.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers can protect their core product IPRs by ensuring contracts clarify that adaptations by Zebracorp do not transfer ownership of the underlying product.
content.source_insight: Offers a tactical solution with example language.
content.text: This potential bone of contention can often be resolved by defining the Zebracorp adaptation in sufficient detail and by adding clarifying language such as: “the foregoing will not be construed to transfer or assign any ownership or title to any intellectual property rights of the supplier in the underlying product but the supplier and its licensors will retain all such rights despite any adaptations made by or for [ZEBRACORP]“, or similar wording to safeguard supplier’s IP ownership in the underlying product.

content.verbatim_text: Note that if Zebracorp provides any specifications or copyrighted material to the supplier, it is important to also mention that Zebracorp’s ownership rights extend to any modifications or further development of any of those Zebracorp materials and information.
content.plain_text: If Zebracorp provides specifications or copyrighted material to a supplier, it is important to explicitly state that Zebracorp's ownership rights also cover any modifications or further developments of those materials.
content.expert_insight: This protects Zebracorp from 'derivative work' claims by suppliers. Without this, a supplier modifying Zebracorp's copyrighted material could potentially claim copyright in the modified version.
content.conditions: Zebracorp provides specifications or copyrighted material to the supplier.
content.justification: States the importance of mentioning extended ownership rights.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must proactively assert its ownership over derivative works created from its materials to prevent suppliers from claiming new IP.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must recognize that modifications to Zebracorp's provided materials will likely remain Zebracorp's property.
content.source_insight: Provides a specific guideline for Zebracorp's IPR protection.
content.text: Note that if Zebracorp provides any specifications or copyrighted material to the supplier, it is important to also mention that Zebracorp’s ownership rights extend to any modifications or further development of any of those Zebracorp materials and information.

content.verbatim_text: The intellectual property that is created as part of the development is typically referred to as ‘foreground IPRs’, ‘results of development’ or similarly, whereas the existing intellectual property that the developer embeds or incorporates into the results of development are generally referred to ‘background IPRs’ or ‘pre-existing IPRs’.
content.plain_text: Intellectual property created during development is called 'foreground IPRs' or 'results of development,' while existing IP embedded by the developer is 'background IPRs' or 'pre-existing IPRs.'
content.expert_insight: This distinction is fundamental in development agreements, as it dictates how new IP (foreground) is treated versus existing IP (background) that is merely incorporated.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: The intellectual property that is created as part of the development is typically referred to as ‘foreground IPRs’, ‘results of development’ or similarly, whereas the existing intellectual property that the developer embeds or incorporates into the results of development are generally referred to ‘background IPRs’ or ‘pre-existing IPRs’.

content.verbatim_text: The ownership should be checked with the respective product owner (product line/product management).
content.plain_text: IPR ownership should be verified with the relevant product owner (product line/product management).
content.expert_insight: Internal alignment is crucial. The product owner's strategic vision for the product will determine the desired IPR ownership structure.
content.justification: Provides a direct instruction for internal process.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must ensure internal consultation to align IPR strategy with product strategy.
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: Direct instruction for Zebracorp's internal process.
content.text: The ownership should be checked with the respective product owner (product line/product management).

content.verbatim_text: Also in cases where Zebracorp pays for the development work, Zebracorp should as a baseline acquire full unrestricted ownership.
content.plain_text: When Zebracorp funds development work, its baseline position should be to acquire full, unrestricted ownership of the resulting IPRs.
content.expert_insight: This is Zebracorp's default and preferred position, reflecting the principle that 'he who pays, owns.' It provides maximum control and flexibility for Zebracorp.
content.conditions: Zebracorp pays for the development work.
content.justification: States Zebracorp's baseline acquisition position.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should strive for full ownership of IPRs in development work it funds.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers performing paid development work for Zebracorp should expect to transfer full IPR ownership.
content.source_insight: Provides Zebracorp's baseline guideline.
content.text: Also in cases where Zebracorp pays for the development work, Zebracorp should as a baseline acquire full unrestricted ownership.

content.verbatim_text: Whenever we agree that Zebracorp does not become the owner of the foreground IPR, we should agree on a broad license (i.e. the right to use) that Zebracorp obtains into such foreground IPR.
content.plain_text: If Zebracorp does not own foreground IPRs, it must secure a broad license (right to use) for them.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical fallback. If ownership isn't secured, a comprehensive license is the next best protection to ensure Zebracorp can utilize the developed IP.
content.conditions: Zebracorp does not become the owner of the foreground IPR.
content.justification: States a necessary action if ownership is not secured.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must ensure it obtains a broad license for foreground IPRs if it does not own them.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers retaining foreground IPR ownership must be prepared to grant a broad license to Zebracorp.
content.source_insight: Provides a guideline for licensing foreground IPRs.
content.text: Whenever we agree that Zebracorp does not become the owner of the foreground IPR, we should agree on a broad license (i.e. the right to use) that Zebracorp obtains into such foreground IPR.

content.verbatim_text: In any event it is important to make sure that license is sufficiently broad/comprehensive to give us the rights we need to exploit the results of development in the manner that we had contemplated.
content.plain_text: It is important to ensure any license obtained is broad and comprehensive enough to allow Zebracorp to exploit the development results as intended.
content.expert_insight: The scope of the license is paramount. A narrow license can severely restrict Zebracorp's ability to use the IP, negating the value of the development work.
content.conditions: When obtaining a license for foreground IPR.
content.justification: Emphasizes the importance of license scope.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must carefully define its intended use of development results to ensure the license covers all necessary exploitation rights.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers granting licenses must understand Zebracorp's intended use to negotiate appropriate license terms.
content.source_insight: Provides a guideline for license scope.
content.text: In any event it is important to make sure that license is sufficiently broad/comprehensive to give us the rights we need to exploit the results of development in the manner that we had contemplated.

content.verbatim_text: As for the background IPRs, Zebracorp will generally only require a license to use such background IP.
content.plain_text: For background IPRs, Zebracorp typically only requires a license for their use.
content.expert_insight: This is a standard practice, as background IP is pre-existing and core to the supplier's business. Zebracorp generally doesn't need to own it, just have the right to use it in conjunction with the foreground IP.
content.conditions: Regarding background IPRs.
content.justification: States Zebracorp's general requirement for background IP.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should focus on securing a robust license for background IPRs rather than seeking ownership.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers can generally retain ownership of their background IPRs, but must be prepared to license them to Zebracorp.
content.source_insight: Provides a guideline for background IPRs.
content.text: As for the background IPRs, Zebracorp will generally only require a license to use such background IP.

content.verbatim_text: In case the development work includes the implementation of any Zebracorp proprietary items, Zebracorp should retain IPR ownership to such proprietary items as default, without any license to the supplier.
content.plain_text: If development work involves Zebracorp's proprietary items, Zebracorp should default to retaining IPR ownership of these items, without granting a license to the supplier.
content.expert_insight: This protects Zebracorp's core, unique IP from being commercialized or misused by the supplier. It's a critical safeguard for competitive advantage.
content.conditions: Development work includes the implementation of Zebracorp proprietary items.
content.justification: States Zebracorp's default position for proprietary items.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must ensure its proprietary items remain its property and are not licensed to suppliers during development.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers working with Zebracorp's proprietary items should not expect to receive a license or ownership of those items.
content.source_insight: Provides a guideline for Zebracorp's proprietary items.
content.text: In case the development work includes the implementation of any Zebracorp proprietary items, Zebracorp should retain IPR ownership to such proprietary items as default, without any license to the supplier.

content.verbatim_text: It is advisable to avoid jointly owned intellectual property rights.
content.plain_text: It is advisable to avoid jointly owned intellectual property rights.
content.expert_insight: Joint ownership often leads to complex management, decision-making deadlocks, and valuation issues, making it highly problematic for commercial exploitation.
content.conditions: N/A
content.justification: States strong advice to avoid a specific type of IPR ownership.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should actively seek sole ownership or clear licensing arrangements instead of joint ownership to avoid future complications.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should also be cautious of joint ownership due to potential future exploitation difficulties.
content.source_insight: Provides strong advice against joint ownership.
content.text: It is advisable to avoid jointly owned intellectual property rights.

content.verbatim_text: Often a better solution is achieved through agreeing on one party owning all of the intellectual property generated as a result of the collaborative innovation/development and on licensing it to the other party on a free-of-charge perpetual basis and with sufficiently broad license terms.
content.plain_text: A better alternative to joint ownership is for one party to own all collaboratively developed IP and license it to the other party on a free, perpetual, and broad basis.
content.expert_insight: This 'sole ownership with broad license' model is generally preferred over joint ownership, providing clarity of title while ensuring both parties can utilize the IP.
content.justification: Suggests an alternative solution to joint ownership.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can use this model to gain full control over IP while still allowing partners to use it under license.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers can propose this model to retain ownership while satisfying Zebracorp's usage needs.
content.source_insight: Offers a tactical alternative to joint ownership.
content.text: Often a better solution is achieved through agreeing on one party owning all of the intellectual property generated as a result of the collaborative innovation/development and on licensing it to the other party on a free-of-charge perpetual basis and with sufficiently broad license terms.

content.verbatim_text: Zebracorp’s own existing intellectual property rights should never be transferred, assigned or sold in an ordinary procurement contract.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp's existing IPRs must never be transferred, assigned, or sold in a standard procurement contract.
content.expert_insight: This is a fundamental rule to protect Zebracorp's core assets. Procurement contracts are for acquiring goods/services, not divesting Zebracorp's foundational IP.
content.conditions: In an ordinary procurement contract.
content.justification: Uses strong prohibitive language 'should never be transferred'.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must rigorously safeguard its existing IPRs and ensure no procurement contract inadvertently transfers them.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should not expect to acquire ownership of Zebracorp's existing IPRs through procurement contracts.
content.source_insight: Provides a critical guideline for Zebracorp's IPRs.
content.text: Zebracorp’s own existing intellectual property rights should never be transferred, assigned or sold in an ordinary procurement contract.

content.verbatim_text: At most we can consider granting limited licenses to use certain specified Zebracorp IPR for the purpose of performing the supplier/subcontractor’s obligations towards Zebracorp.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp may consider granting limited licenses for specific Zebracorp IPRs, solely for suppliers/subcontractors to fulfill their obligations to Zebracorp.
content.expert_insight: This is the only permissible scenario for outbound licensing of Zebracorp's core IP within a procurement context. Strict limitations are essential.
content.conditions: For the purpose of performing the supplier/subcontractor’s obligations towards Zebracorp.
content.justification: States the maximum extent of IPR licensing for Zebracorp.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must ensure any outbound licenses for its IPRs are strictly limited in scope and purpose.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers may receive limited licenses to Zebracorp's IPRs, but only for the purpose of performing their contractual duties.
content.source_insight: Provides a guideline for Zebracorp's outbound licensing.
content.text: At most we can consider granting limited licenses to use certain specified Zebracorp IPR for the purpose of performing the supplier/subcontractor’s obligations towards Zebracorp.

content.verbatim_text: In such event it is worthwhile specifying that the license is limited, non-exclusive, revocable, and granted solely for such purpose, and for no other purpose whatsoever.
content.plain_text: When granting a limited license, it is crucial to specify that it is limited, non-exclusive, revocable, and granted solely for the stated purpose, and no other.
content.expert_insight: These are essential protective measures. Each of these terms restricts the supplier's rights and preserves Zebracorp's control over its IP.
content.conditions: When granting limited licenses to Zebracorp IPR.
content.justification: States specific, critical conditions for such licenses.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must ensure these protective terms are included in any limited license granted to suppliers.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers receiving such a license must understand its strict limitations.
content.source_insight: Provides critical conditions for Zebracorp's outbound licenses.
content.text: In such event it is worthwhile specifying that the license is limited, non-exclusive, revocable, and granted solely for such purpose, and for no other purpose whatsoever.

content.verbatim_text: Where needed, please consult a member of the Legal & Compliance team to assist with the correct wording.
content.plain_text: Consult a Legal & Compliance team member for assistance with correct wording when needed.
content.expert_insight: Legal expertise is vital for drafting precise IPR clauses to avoid ambiguity and ensure enforceability.
content.justification: Provides a direct instruction for seeking legal assistance.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp personnel should engage legal counsel for drafting critical IPR clauses.
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: Direct instruction for internal process.
content.text: Where needed, please consult a member of the Legal & Compliance team to assist with the correct wording.

content.verbatim_text: Any other license to Zebracorp IPR should be subject to a separate written license agreement.
content.plain_text: Any license to Zebracorp IPR beyond the limited scope for supplier obligations must be formalized in a separate written license agreement.
content.expert_insight: This ensures that significant outbound licenses are properly vetted, documented, and not embedded inappropriately within procurement contracts, which are not designed for IP commercialization.
content.conditions: Any license to Zebracorp IPR not solely for supplier's performance of obligations.
content.justification: States a clear rule for handling other IPR licenses.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must use dedicated license agreements for any broad or commercial licensing of its IPRs.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers seeking broader licenses to Zebracorp IPRs should expect a separate, dedicated license agreement.
content.source_insight: Provides a critical guideline for Zebracorp's IPR licensing.
content.text: Any other license to Zebracorp IPR should be subject to a separate written license agreement.

content.verbatim_text: Care should be taken with Feedback and Residuals clauses, as the suppliers quite often expect to get a full license (including patents) in particular to the Feedback (see the Confidentiality Clause in this document).
content.plain_text: Exercise caution with Feedback and Residuals clauses, as suppliers often expect broad licenses, including patents, for feedback provided.
content.expert_insight: These clauses can inadvertently grant away valuable IP rights. Zebracorp needs to carefully review and limit the scope of any licenses granted based on supplier feedback or residual knowledge.
content.conditions: When dealing with Feedback and Residuals clauses.
content.justification: Provides a cautionary guideline for specific clauses.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must carefully scrutinize Feedback and Residuals clauses to avoid unintentionally granting broad IPR licenses to suppliers.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers often seek broad rights to feedback they provide, including patent licenses.
content.source_insight: Provides a cautionary guideline for specific contract clauses.
content.text: Care should be taken with Feedback and Residuals clauses, as the suppliers quite often expect to get a full license (including patents) in particular to the Feedback (see the Confidentiality Clause in this document).

content.verbatim_text: The above does not apply to any development agreements where it is in fact mandatory to agree specifically which party will become the owner of the results of the development and how pre-existing IPR will be treated.
content.plain_text: The general rule of each party retaining its IPRs does not apply to development agreements, where it is mandatory to specifically agree on ownership of development results and treatment of pre-existing IPR.
content.expert_insight: Development agreements are a key exception to the 'retain your own IP' rule. They inherently involve creation of new IP, necessitating explicit ownership and licensing terms.

content.implication_company: Zebracorp must ensure explicit IPR ownership and pre-existing IPR treatment are defined in all development agreements.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers in development agreements must be prepared to negotiate and agree on IPR ownership and treatment of pre-existing IPR.
content.source_insight: Provides a critical exception to a general rule.
content.text: The above does not apply to any development agreements where it is in fact mandatory to agree specifically which party will become the owner of the results of the development and how pre-existing IPR will be treated.

content.verbatim_text: Any material deviations and variations to the terms to the IPR provisions of the respective Zebracorp development agreements templates are recommended to be reviewed by Legal & Compliance.
content.plain_text: Material deviations from the IPR provisions in Zebracorp's development agreement templates should be reviewed by Legal & Compliance.

content.verbatim_text: Intellectual property rights or IPRs are the rights given to individuals or companies over their inventions or other creations. They usually give the inventor/creator an exclusive right over the use of its invention/creation for a certain period of time.
content.plain_text: Intellectual property rights (IPRs) are exclusive rights granted to individuals or companies over their inventions or creations for a specific period.
content.expert_insight: This foundational definition highlights the core concept of IPRs: exclusive rights for a limited duration, encouraging innovation by protecting creators' interests.

content.implication_supplier: N/A

content.text: Intellectual property rights or IPRs are the rights given to individuals or companies over their inventions or other creations. They usually give the inventor/creator an exclusive right over the use of its invention/creation for a certain period of time.

content.verbatim_text: The most common types of intellectual property rights include patents, copyrights and trademarks.
content.plain_text: The primary categories of intellectual property rights are patents, copyrights, and trademarks.

content.verbatim_text: Patents are granted by state authorities in various countries to certain inventions that provide a solution to a specific technological problem.
content.plain_text: Patents are state-granted rights for inventions that solve a specific technological problem.
content.expert_insight: This defines patents by their granting authority, purpose, and subject matter.

content.verbatim_text: In order to be patentable, the invention must meet relevant patentability requirements, such as novelty, usefulness and nonobviousness.
content.plain_text: For an invention to be patentable, it must satisfy specific requirements, including novelty, usefulness, and non-obviousness.
content.expert_insight: These are the fundamental criteria for patent eligibility. Companies seeking to patent inventions must ensure these are met; suppliers developing patentable solutions must also adhere to these standards.
content.conditions: An invention is being considered for patentability.
content.justification: These are legal requirements for patent grants.
content.implication_company: Must ensure internal inventions meet these criteria to secure patents.
content.implication_supplier: Must ensure any inventions developed for or with Zebracorp meet these criteria if patent protection is desired.

content.text: In order to be patentable, the invention must meet relevant patentability requirements, such as novelty, usefulness and nonobviousness.

content.verbatim_text: The exclusive right granted to a patent holder is not the “sole right to use” but the right to prevent others from making, using, selling, or distributing the patented invention without the patent holders’ permission.
content.plain_text: A patent holder's exclusive right is not to solely use the invention, but to prevent others from making, using, selling, or distributing it without permission.
content.expert_insight: This clarifies a common misconception about patent rights, emphasizing their defensive nature (right to exclude) rather than an affirmative right to use, which might be restricted by other patents.
content.justification: N/A

content.implication_supplier: N/A

content.text: The exclusive right granted to a patent holder is not the “sole right to use” but the right to prevent others from making, using, selling, or distributing the patented invention without the patent holders’ permission.

content.verbatim_text: Copyright laws give creator of a certain piece of work exclusive rights to it.
content.plain_text: Copyright laws grant creators exclusive rights over their original works.

content.verbatim_text: In order to obtain copyright the work should meet minimal standards of originality.
content.plain_text: To obtain copyright, a work must meet minimal originality standards.
content.expert_insight: Originality is the core requirement for copyright protection. This means the work must be independently created and possess at least some minimal degree of creativity.
content.conditions: A work is being considered for copyright protection.
content.justification: This is a fundamental legal requirement for copyright.
content.implication_company: Ensure internal creative works (e.g., software, reports) are original to secure copyright.
content.implication_supplier: Ensure works delivered to Zebracorp meet originality standards if copyright is expected to vest.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: In order to obtain copyright the work should meet minimal standards of originality.

content.verbatim_text: Copyright does not cover ideas and information themselves but merely the form or manner in which they are expressed. Accordingly, it is possible for two individuals to have copyright to substantially similar work.
content.plain_text: Copyright protects the expression of ideas and information, not the ideas or information themselves, allowing for similar works to be independently copyrighted.
content.expert_insight: This distinction is crucial: copyright protects the specific way something is written or depicted, not the underlying concept. This explains why two people can independently create similar works and both hold copyright.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Copyright does not cover ideas and information themselves but merely the form or manner in which they are expressed. Accordingly, it is possible for two individuals to have copyright to substantially similar work.

content.verbatim_text: Also, unlike patents and trademarks, copyrights do not generally need to be applied with any state authorities but most jurisdictions recognize copyright in any completed work, without any formal registrations.
content.plain_text: Unlike patents and trademarks, copyrights are generally recognized upon creation of a work, without the need for formal registration with state authorities in most jurisdictions.
content.expert_insight: This highlights a key procedural difference for copyright, which is often automatic upon creation, simplifying protection but potentially complicating enforcement without registration.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Also, unlike patents and trademarks, copyrights do not generally need to be applied with any state authorities but most jurisdictions recognize copyright in any completed work, without any formal registrations.

content.verbatim_text: Trademarks are distinctive names, symbols or designs or combination of all of the above, that identify a company or products and services.
content.plain_text: Trademarks are unique names, symbols, designs, or combinations thereof, used to identify a company, its products, or services.
content.expert_insight: This defines trademarks by their purpose (identification) and form (distinctive marks).

content.verbatim_text: in development agreements or any such agreements where the supplier is contracted to deliver certain work results to Zebracorp (in e.g. consultancy agreements) we should expressly agree on the ownership of the results of the development or other work.
content.plain_text: In development or consultancy agreements where a supplier delivers work results to Zebracorp, explicit agreement on the ownership of those results is required.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical rule for Zebracorp to protect its investment in custom development. Without explicit agreement, default rules (creator ownership) might apply, which is usually not in Zebracorp's interest when paying for custom work.
content.conditions: Applicable to development agreements or agreements where a supplier delivers work results to Zebracorp.
content.justification: To avoid disputes and ensure Zebracorp obtains rights to work it pays for.
content.implication_company: Must ensure IPR ownership clauses are explicitly included and agreed upon in relevant contracts.
content.implication_supplier: Should expect to negotiate and agree on IPR ownership for work results delivered to Zebracorp.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: in development agreements or any such agreements where the supplier is contracted to deliver certain work results to Zebracorp (in e.g. consultancy agreements) we should expressly agree on the ownership of the results of the development or other work.

content.verbatim_text: In the absence of such agreement, the IPRs will generally vest with the party that made the invention or created the work.
content.plain_text: If no specific agreement on IPR ownership exists, the rights typically belong to the party that created the invention or work.
content.expert_insight: This highlights the default legal position, underscoring why explicit agreements (as per the previous guideline) are crucial for Zebracorp when it is commissioning work.
content.justification: N/A

content.implication_supplier: Will retain IPR ownership by default if no agreement specifies otherwise.
